pbi.title: As a user, I want a global CLI for backlog-chef so that I can process transcripts from anywhere on my system
pbi.description: Implement an OCLIF-based CLI that allows global installation and command-line processing of meeting transcripts. The CLI will provide a professional interface for using the backlog-chef tool.
acceptance_criteria: User can install globally with "npm install -g backlog-chef"
User can run "backlog-chef process [file]" to process any transcript
All three input formats (TXT, JSON, XML) work seamlessly
Auto-generated help text explains all options
"npm start" still works for local development
Proper error messages when files don't exist or API keys missing
Documentation updated with CLI usage examples
notes: Future commands may include validate, analyze, and config

strengths: Clear user story with defined goal
concerns: Potential complexity in supporting multiple input formats

risk_flags.message: Multiple input format support could introduce parsing challenges and increase code complexity
Global npm installation may require careful package.json configuration to ensure proper executable path resolution
Lack of specific performance requirements could lead to inefficient transcript processing for large files
Insufficient error handling could result in poor user experience with unclear failure modes during transcript processing

suggestions: Add explicit performance benchmarks for transcript processing, specifying maximum acceptable processing time per file size category
Define comprehensive error handling strategy with specific error codes and user-friendly messages for common failure scenarios like invalid file formats or permission issues
Include TypeScript type definitions for CLI command arguments and configuration to ensure strong type safety and improve developer experience
Specify the minimum required Node.js version and any critical system dependencies needed for global CLI installation
Create a detailed configuration section outlining supported transcript formats, input validation rules, and default processing behaviors

risks.description: Complex input format parsing across multiple transcript types could introduce significant implementation challenges and potential parsing errors
risks.mitigation: Create an extensible input format adapter pattern, implement comprehensive input validation, and develop a standardized parsing interface with clear error handling

risks.description: Global npm installation may encounter configuration challenges with executable path resolution and system compatibility
risks.mitigation: Carefully configure package.json, test installation across multiple OS environments, and provide explicit installation instructions with potential workarounds

risks.description: Lack of explicit performance requirements could lead to inefficient implementation and potential scalability issues
risks.mitigation: Define clear performance benchmarks for transcript processing, implement profiling, and establish maximum processing time thresholds per file size category

risks.description: Insufficient error handling strategy could expand scope through repeated refinements and user experience improvements
risks.mitigation: Develop comprehensive error handling framework with standardized error codes, create detailed error documentation, and implement flexible logging mechanisms

blocking_issues: Some high and critical unanswered questions remain
warnings: Potential complexity in multiple input format support
recommendations: Define specific performance benchmarks for CLI operations
Clarify and resolve remaining unanswered questions
Create a comprehensive backwards compatibility testing plan
Specify exact performance requirements for different input formats
